description:
Owners of Eight Sleep smart beds got anything but a good night’s sleep Monday, as the beds began heating up uncontrollably while also getting frozen in position due to Amazon’s worldwide server outage. 

Eight Sleep CEO Matteo Franceschetti took to X to apologize for the malfunctioning “Pod” smart beds, which cost $2,600 and up, and he promised that the company would work “24/7” to “outage-proof” the beds. That fix is rolling out now, the company told TechHive.

“The AWS outage has impacted some of our users since last night, disrupting their sleep,” Franceschetti wrote on X. “That is not the experience we want to provide and I want to apologize for it.” 

Furious Eight Sleep owners vented on Reddit, describing how thei
title: These smart beds began roasting their owners during AWS outage

description:
We’re in the long, dark teatime of technology deals at the moment, between back-to-school and Black Friday. So, it might be another month or so before you see a bunch of great monitor deals. Here’s a preview: An MSI 27-inch OLED gaming monitor, and one that’s much faster than usual, for $130 off. Today you can get it for $519.99, straight from MSI itself.

The MAG 271QP looks more or less like all the other 27-inch OLEDs out there, with a fairly typical frame and 2560x1440p resolution. But at 280Hz refresh, complete with AdaptiveSync support, it can handle much faster competitive online gaming than some of the other deals in this price range. But keep in mind, this is very much for desktop gaming — you get two HDMI 2.1 ports and one DisplayPort, so multiple PCs or consoles are welcome, bu
title: This super-fast MSI OLED gaming monitor is just $520 today

description:
The new ROG Xbox Ally handheld costs $600, despite Asus’ implication that it’s for “casual gamers.” And if you want a better processor and other upgraded specs, you’ll need to spend a whopping $1,000 for the Xbox Ally X. If you’re feeling sticker shock at those prices, Microsoft says you should blame Asus.

Okay, the company didn’t put it in those exact words. When talking with Variety (spotted by Tom’s
title: Microsoft points finger at Asus for the ROG Xbox Ally’s hefty pricing

description:
SpaceX’s Starlink satellite network has reached a new milestone. As of this past weekend, the company launched its 10,000th Starlink satellite into orbit, marking a new record in space history.

10,000 Starlink satellites in space

Two Falcon 9 rockets were launched from California and Florida on Sunday, carrying a total of 56 new satellites into orbit, as SpaceX announced on social media. This means the company has officially passed the 10,000 mark for satellites launched.

According to astrophysicist
title: Starlink reaches 10,000 satellites launched, but not without consequences

description: Today, Meta announced that it has begun rolling out a range of new tools and features to protect its users from fraud, scams, and other cybersecurity risks on the company’s social media platforms, which include Facebook, Instagram, Threads, WhatsApp, and Messenger.
title: Meta ramps up scam detection features in WhatsApp and Messenger

description:
Intel has a lot going on at the moment–and some of it even has to do with chips! With apologies for the ribbing, Intel’s new Panther Lake CPU family really is looking to be a huge shakeup when it lands in laptops next year. And on The Full Nerd podcast later today, we’ve got Intel’s Tom Peterson to talk about it.

Tom’s an industry veteran and a frequent guest, both on The Full Nerd and PCWorld’s live coverage on YouTube. We’re particularly interested in the expanded integrated graphical powers of Panther Lake, which gets a 50 percent core count boost over the last generation in addition to the greater technical capabiliti
title: Intel’s Tom Petersen joins us on The Full Nerd Podcast, TODAY

description:
Microsoft is giving the Widgets panel in Windows 11 a major facelift with the Windows 11 25H2 update, reports Windows Latest. The new version of the Discover feed now has a more modern look with rounded corners, clearer structure, and support for multiple dashboards.

Dashboards can now be grouped together in a left-hand menu, while the feed will have a greater focus on AI-curated content via Copilot. The “Curated by Copilot” feature allows Microsoft’s AI assistant to curate news and articles from MSN sources based on the user’s interests.

You might remember that Widgets were originally introduced in Windows Vista under the name Gadgets. The feature later disappeared, only to return in Windows 11 as Wi
title: Microsoft gives Windows 11’s Widgets panel a much-needed makeover

description:
Microsoft has responded to a serious problem with Windows 11, where installing update KB5066835 can break USB keyboards and mice, preventing them from working in the Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE) and leaving you unable to do anything.

As of yesterday, Microsoft has released two emergency out-of-band updates to address the issue: KB5070762 and
title: Microsoft drops emergency Windows 11 update, fixing USB input bug

description:
In my work as a tech reviewer, I’ve had plenty of opportunities to test $300 keyboards with overly advanced tech inside and mice capable of tracking subtle movements so precisely they could almost surely be hacked to record my voice (thanks for the paranoia, Tom’s Hardware).

But as much as I love the ultimate tech accessories—give me that 8,000Hz polling rate, adjustable actuation depth, plush wrist rest, heavy metal base—there are plenty of times when such gear isn’t necessary. That’s where this cheap Arteck keyboard-trac
title: I hate typing with a TV remote. That’s why I love this nifty $36 gadget

description:
There’s a new version of Outlook for Windows, basically a web skin. A lot of people aren’t thrilled about it and are still using the older, standalone version for its better offline capabilities. Unless they can’t… because a weird bug is making error messages pop up and Exchange logins are failing. If you’ve been seeing the alert box above, give it another try — Microsoft says it should be fixed now.

Bleeping Computer spotted the
title: Microsoft squashes bug keeping the old Outlook from launching

description:
Just a little more than a month after the top exec for HBO Max mused that the service is “way underpriced,” the streamer is following through with a price hike for each of its three tiers. 

Starting today for new subscribers, the price of HBO Max Premium will go up to $22.99, a $2-a-month increase, while the annual rate for Premium will rise to $229.99, up $20 a year. The step-down HBO Max Standard plan is also getting a price hike to $18.49 a month, up $1.50/month, with the annual Standard price going up to $184.99, a $15 annual increase. Finally, HBO Max Basic with Ads is now $10.99, up a dollar a month, while the annual rate for that plan is getting hiked to $109.99 a year, up $10 annually. 

Existing HBO Max monthly subscribers will see the price increases take effect on their next bills after November 20, 2025, while current subscrib
title: HBO Max is hiking prices, just like its chief exec said it would

description:
If you’re thinking of buying a new USB flash drive, maybe hold your horses and consider getting this SK Hynix Tube T31 portable SSD instead. Not only is it lightning fast with better performance than a typical flash drive, but it actually has a flash drive form factor. In other words, it looks like a flash drive but performs like an SSD. How great is that? And it’s on sale right now: 2TB for just $118.98 (was $159.99, now 26% off).

We reviewed this portable SSD a while ago and we loved it for its fast performance, compact size, and overall value. It earned a strong 4.5-star rating and our reviewing expert even ended up using it as his daily drive, which really speaks to how good it is considering
title: This 2TB portable SSD that looks like a flash drive just hit its best price yet

description:
What to do if you’re a gamer who prioritizes visual speed above all else, but you’re stuck on a tight budget? No problem! We’ve found an absolutely jaw-dropping deal that’s perfect for you: the 27-inch Asus ROG Strix XG279CNS that’s capable of pushing a super-fast 380Hz refresh rate is now, for the first time, slashed down by 29%… so it can be yours for a stunningly affordable $249 (was $349).

This is a fantastic deal because super-high refresh rates are still premium and therefore pricey. If you’re okay making concessions elsewhere, this might just be the cheapest way to get a 380Hz monitor for a long time, so consider jumping on it before this deal vanishes.

At 27 inches, it’s neither too big nor too small, taking up just enough space on your desk and no more. (Sadly, no VESA mount he
title: This 27-inch 1080p 380Hz IPS monitor is a steal for just $249 today

description:
If you’re looking for a powerful gaming laptop that can get you playing all the best games with Nvidia’s latest DLSS 4 tech without breaking the bank, then this Lenovo Legion 5i with a stellar configuration is the one for you. It’s currently on sale at B&H for just $1,249.99, which is a massive $450 off its original $1,699.99 and one of the best prices we’ve seen for a laptop with specs like this. Supplies are limited so act fast!

This Lenovo Legion 5i is a powerhouse in every way, clearly built to tackle whatever tasks you need to handle during the day and then effortlessly run all the games you could possibly want to play at night. The RTX 5060 GPU is the pièce de résistance here, but the rest of the machine ain’t a slouch either. You’re
title: An RTX 5060 OLED laptop with a $450 discount? This deal is crazy!

description:
Recall is a feature in Windows 11 that regularly creates screen recordings and saves them locally. This also involves processing with AI so that users can search through the data. The aim is to make past work steps, websites, or documents retrievable via a search feature.

Microsoft first introduced Recall in 2024, but withdrew it after massive criticism due to insufficient security. The feature has been integrated again since the current versions of Windows 11 from 24H2. In Europe, it is available as an opt-in and can be completely deactivated or removed.

Access is via a timeline or by entering keywords in the search. The results appear regardless of the program or browser window in which the content was originally visible.
title: Windows Recall might be storing more data than you think. Here’s what to do

description:
Mini PCs are all the rage these days, beating out both laptops and desktop PCs in straight-up comparisons of performance-per-dollar. You can usually spot at least one mini PC model on sale in any given week, but it’s rare for a high-end mini PC brand like Minisforum to go on sale. If you’re in the market for a quality option, today’s your lucky day.

Right now, the Minisforum UM870 Slim mini PC is 20% off on Amazon, slashing its price down from its original $599.90 to a much more affordable and value-packed $479.90. That’s an incredible price for a machine that’s as robust, powerful, and elegant as this one is.

Let’s talk power. This mini PC runs on an AMD Ryzen 7 8745H processor and a solid 32GB of DDR5 RAM as well as a spacious 1TB Gen 4 SSD. It may be tiny, but it ain’t slow or weak—t
title: Upgrade your laptop to this premium Ryzen mini PC for 20% off

description:
1. What is search parameter injection?

Search parameter injection attacks are a new, sophisticated method used by criminals to obtain your data or even gain access to your PC.

Criminals place adverts on Google that are displayed whenever someone searches for the word “support” and a specific company, such as “support Netflix.” The advert appears directly above the first search hit and is designed to look as if it comes from Netflix itself.

Anyone who clicks on this advert is — and this is the special thing about this scam — not directed to a fake website, but to the original Netflix support website. However, the attackers have entered their own telephone number in the search function on the support page (see image).
title: Worried about hackers, viruses, and fraud? Ask yourself these 10 questions

description:
If you’ve been waiting to get a new tablet that can support the latest iPadOS 26, there’s never been a better time. That’s because the iPad Air M3 in Starlight with 5G cellular and 512GB of storage is down to $970, a savings of $279, and the best price we’ve ever seen.

With its 13-inch Liquid Retina Display and powerful M3 chip, the iPad Air delivers stunning visuals and lightning-fast performance no matter what you’re using it for: drawing, playing games, or just searching stuff on Safari. We gave this tablet a fantastic 4-star review alongside our Editors’ Choice award, praising its display and performance. We also really appre
title: This loaded 13-inch iPad Air just dropped to a brand new low price
